ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned about different methods and assays used in the field of reproductive biology.
Skills for basic science labs such as western blot, immunohistochemistry and H&E
I learned a lot of important laboratory techniques such as Western blotting and PCR reactions.
Many protein-based web lab techniques (immunohistochemistry, Western blot, H&E staining) as well as RT-PCR for RNA work
I learned many useful research techniques

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The labs were interesting and pretty interactive. I thought the papers chosen for discussion were interesting and relevant to the topics we discussed.
Very informative and well tailored for the need of the students!

The techniques we learned in the class are used a lot in a laboratory setting, so it was great to become familiar with those protocols. The papers we read detailed how the techniques are used in a practical sense and also got us to more practice with how to read papers. Some days only required us to spend around an hour in the lab to do final steps and look at our slides, but I appreciated the thoroughness in the protocol, since that's what we would encounter in a real lab setting.
Professor Whirledge is the strength of this course. She was an excellent teacher, very patient and helpful.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This lab was in person so there wasn't much change besides distancing, etc.
The in person format was so great.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: YES! It was the best MCDB lab course I've taken. It is really interesting material if you are interested in reproductive biology, and the professors are organized and very approachable. I really enjoyed taking this lab!
Yes, it's a great lab and not too much work.

One of the best MCDB labs offered; definitely take it if you can! The homework is reasonable, and the professors really care about what you learn from the class as opposed to how well you follow directions or protocol.
Yes!! I would recommend this to both science and non-science majors.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Mostly in-person lab, with ~3 labs/meetings being virtual
